texts.shortText: Colonial hydroid with stiff, upright, bright-yellow stems, each bearing alternating lateral branches of decreasing length that all lie in a single plane. Larger side-branches may branch again. Both the main stem and side-branches bear polyps on both sides and each of these emerges from a projecting hydrotheca, which when the polyp is retracted is closed by a 4-sided, pyramid-shaped operculum. If present, reproductive individuals (gonothecae) are spindle-shaped and are born singly and often far out from the main stem.
Stems typically 50 mm tall, but up to 300 mm reported, gonothecae about 2 mm.

Global: Australia, Southern Africa, Vema Seamount.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to Mozambique.
Widely distributed on rocky reefs and in sheltered pools although also recorded down to 219 m depth. Always orientated at right angles to the predominant water flow.
Presumed to feed on small particles and planktonic organisms in the water.
Colonies spread asexually by putting up new stems from the creeping ‘roots’. There are separate males and females and fertilized eggs develop within the female gonothecae to form planula larvae.

Distinctive stiff, flat appearance is unusual, but easily confused with members of the closely-related genus Thuiaria, which have similar colony form, but the side branches come off in pairs (not alternately to left and right) and the polyps are sunken into the stems.

Although all existing guides depict and name this species, in reality there are over 20 easily-confused local species in the genus and some of the images depicted on local websites appear to depict species other than S. arbuscula.
